metadata.title: A study on performance, combustion and emission behaviour of diesel engine powered by novel nano nerium oleander biofuel

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
A study on performance, combustion and emission behaviour of diesel engine powered by novel nano nerium oleander biofuel
B. Dhinesh, M. Annamalai
PII: S0959-6526(18)31650-0 DOI: 10.1016/j.jclepro.2018.06.002 Reference: JCLP 13148 To appear in: Journal of Cleaner Production
Received Date: 09 September 2017 Accepted Date: 01 June 2018
Please cite this article as: B. Dhinesh, M. Annamalai, A study on performance, combustion and emission behaviour of diesel engine powered by novel nano nerium oleander biofuel, Journal of (2018), doi: 10.1016/j.jclepro.2018.06.002Cleaner Production
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
1 A study on performance, combustion and emission behaviour of 2 diesel engine powered by novel nano nerium oleander biofuel 3 a* Dhinesh. B, b Annamalai M, 4 a Assistant Professor, Department of Mechanical Engineering, b, Department of Automobile 5 Engineering 6 a, Mepco Schlenk Engineering College, Sivakasi, Virudhunagar, Tamil Nadu - 626005
7 b, Madras Institute of Technology campus, Anna University, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India.
8 a*Corresponding Author: Email: dhineshbala91@gmail.com;
9 Mobile Number: +91-979625490
10 11 Abstract 12 In connection with the threating environmental pollution and stringent emission 13 norms, the present experimental research studies the effect of utilizing cerium oxide 14 nanoparticle mixed with an emulsion of nerium oleander biofuel (ENOB) on a 15 compression ignition (CI) direct injection (DI) diesel engine. The whole probe was 16 persuaded using a mono-cylinder 4-stroke direct injection CI engine. A novel nerium 17 olender biofuel was extracted and esterified. Later it was converted into the emulsion 18 of nerium oleander biofuel, that ensued in diluted oxides of nitrogen and in reduced 19 smoke opacity emission. However it produced a marginal penalty of CO and HC 20 emission when equated with neat nerium oleander biofuel. Subsequently, the nano 21 particle blended emulsion of nerium oleander biofuel depicted dramatic diminution in 22 CO, smoke opacity, HC, and NOx emission when equated with standard fossil diesel, 23 neat nerium oleander biofuel and an emulsion of nerium oleander biofuel at various
24 power outputs. It was concluded that the nano emulsion of nerium oleander biofuel 25 could be used in direct injection, compression ignition engines without any hardware 26 alterations in the engine.
27 Keywords: Biofuel; Environmental pollution; Emulsion of nerium oleander biofuel; 28 Cerium oxide nanoparticle; Emission; Diesel engine.

sections.heading: 29 1. Introduction
sections.text:
30 Rudolf diesel devised the compression ignition engine; it has dominated the 31 world since its inception. By considering the reliability, robust construction and higher 32 brake thermal efficiency characteristics, it has become democratic in the world. Despite 33 having several merits, they endure from a high level of exhaust emissions such as oxides 34 of nitrogen and smoke opacity. Those emissions affect both the environment and the 35 human health. High demand and lavish consumption have led to the depletion of fossil 36 fuels like petroleum products and government’s strict emission standard forced us to 37 use alternative fuels such as ethanol, n-butanol, dimethyl ethers, mimusops elengi linn 38 and cotton methyl ester (Pedrozo et al. 2016; Zhang and Balasubramanian, 2016; Bora 39 et al. 2014; Hazar, 2010). 40 Researchers from all over the world have performed several experimental studies using 41 biodiesel such as palm, jatropha, orange, Garcinia gummi-gutta (Subramani et al. 2018) 42 and moringa oils in diesel engines. They all reported reduced brake thermal efficiency 43 (BTE) and brake specific fuel consumption (BSFC), when equated with standard fossil 44 diesel fuel because of the fuel’s higher viscosity (Lalvani et al 2015; 2016). The 45 emissions such as HC, CO could be reduced, whereas the oxides of nitrogen emission 46 are increased when equated with diesel fuel due to the presence of oxygen content in
47 the biodiesel fuels. Transesterification is a chemical process, through which the 48 vegetable oil is converted into a biodiesel. There are also several kinds of literature 49 where biofuels such as Cymbopogon flexuosus, eucalyptus oil, pine oil, and turpentine 50 oil are used for the diesel engine combustion. These raw oils also resulted in higher 51 emission level (Dhinesh et al 2016) and hence, the modern biofuel research is focused 52 on the emulsification of biofuel. It is a technique, which is used to mix two immiscible 53 liquids using a surfactant. The liquids considered are generally biofuel and water. The 54 emulsion is one of the techniques used for the simultaneous reduction of smoke and 55 NOx emissions (Ramalingam et al. 2018).
56 Investigations have been conducted on different emulsified fuels such as palm oil 57 methyl ester, water-diesel emulsion, and animal fat emulsion powered diesel engine. 58 The BTE and BSFC were ameliorated for emulsified fuel when equated with non59 emulsified fuel because of micro-explosion and secondary atomization. The tailpipe 60 emission such as oxides of nitrogen and smoke was reduced drastically because of the 61 presence of water content in the emulsified fuel, which in turn reduced the overall 62 combustion chamber temperature (Kumar et al. 2009; Kumar et al. 2005; Debnath et al. 63 2013; Prakash et al. 2015). Among the known biofuels, nerium oleander biofuel (NOB) 64 has been paid very less attention by the researchers all over the world. Researcher such 65 as Kumar et al. (2014) and Lalvani et al. (2015) has done an experimental research on 66 diesel engine using nerium oleander biodiesel. In these researchers, neat NOB is 67 converted to nerium oleander biodiesel through the transesterification chemical process 68 as neat nerium oleander biodiesel shows inferior performance; to ameliorate the 69 performance of neat nerium oleander biodiesel, it is blended with diesel; 20% ofa
70 nerium oleander biodiesel and 80% of standard fossil diesel blend shows better 71 performance. It ha as been found that while yielding nerium oleander biodiesel, a large 72 quantity of fuel is lost due to transesterification process. Out of the obtained nerium 73 oleander biodiesel, only 20% nerium oleander biodiesel could be utilized in this work.
74 In the automotive engines sector, nanotechnology is used specifically to improve the 75 performance and to reduce the emission of the diesel engine. Researchers have studied 76 the functioning features of a diesel engine using dissimilar nanoparticle additives such 77 as alumina, ceria, zinc oxide and carbon nanotubes (CNT) are added separately as well 78 as doped to the jatropha biodiesel fuel. Significant improvement in the BTE that is 79 closer to neat diesel fuel was observed for the nanoparticles blended test fuels owing to 80 increased calorific value of the test fuel and faster evaporation rate along with a 81 dramatic reduction of carbon monoxide, nitric oxide, unburned hydrocarbon, and smoke 82 opacity emissions was also reported for various test fuels by Arockiasamy, & Anand, 83 2015 ; Prabu, & Anand, 2016; Sajith et al. 2010; Basha, & Anand, 2013 ; Javed et al. 84 2016. In particular, Basha, & Anand, (2013b) tested the aluminum oxide nanoparticles 85 blended water-diesel emulsion fuel using a diesel engine for studying the performance, 86 combustion analysis and emission magnitude. The results demonstrated a substantial 87 reduction in the harmful exhaust pollutants due to the addition of alumina nanoparticles 88 in the fuel. Aluminum oxide nanoparticles blended water-diesel emulsion fuel also 89 increased the performance of the nano emulsified fuel and it would separate the 90 hydrogen atoms present in the water molecules and involve them in combustion 91 processes as reported by Basha, & Anand, (2013b). Dhinesh et al. (2016b) conducted 92 the experimental investigation on Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel using ceria nano
93 additive in DI CI engine. A different mass fraction of the nanoparticle such as 10, 20 94 and 30 parts per million is added to the Cymbopogon flexuosus biofuel. The benefits of 95 adding nano additive in biofuel are to ameliorate the diesel engine performance and to 96 dilute the exhaust tailpipe emissions simultaneously. The amelioration of diesel engine 97 performance and reduced tailpipe emission can be attributed to the fuel’s oxidizing and 98 reducing catalytic activity on cerium oxide nanoparticle additive in Cymbopogon 99 flexuosus biofuel-powered by direct injection compression ignition engine. Annamalai 100 et al. (2016) studied the performance and emission behavior of cerium oxide nano 101 particle blended lemongrass emulsion biofuel using a mono-cylinder diesel engine. The 102 dosage level of 30 ppm of nano particle blended biofuel showed a significant reduction 103 in environmental pollution when equated with neat standard fossil diesel. Based on the 104 review of relevant literature and experimental observation, an optimum range of 30 ppm 105 of ceria nanoparticle was chosen for this study.
106 From the literature survey, the current research is focused on utilizing a novel biofuel 107 that is not highly explored in the aspect of the emulsification. The biofuel preferred is 108 nerium olender, which is highly available in the Indian continent. In the aspect of the 109 enhancing the performance characteristics and emission magnitude, the diesel engine 110 was powered by ENOB. Further to ameliorate the performance and to reduce the 111 environmental pollution ceria nanoparticle was dispersed in the emulsion of nerium 112 oleander biofuel with an optimum dosage of 30 ppm. This research work initially 113 describes the synthesis of the nano particle preferred, Outline of the nerium olender 114 biofuel, test fuel preparation and the engine setup in the materials and methods and 115 section. Later on, in the result and discussion section, the diesel engines performance,
116 emission and combustion characteristics are studied as on fueled with the Standard fuel 117 diesel fuel (SFDF), nerium olender biofuel (NOB), emulsion of nerium olender biofuel 118 (ENOB) and nano emulsion of nerium olender biofuel (NENOB) at various power 119 outputs.
120 2. Materials and method 121 2.1 Synthesis of CeO2 nanoparticles 122 The synthesis of cerium oxide (ceria) nanoparticle was carried out by the sol-gel 123 combustion process. A required quantity of deionized water, an appropriate amount of 124 glycine and cerium nitrate hexahydrate are dissolved in the beaker. The concentration 125 of cerium nitrate hexahydrate preferred was 1 molar and the glycine concentration was 126 about 0.2 molar. The obtained solution was kept under constant stirring in an operating 127 condition of 70oC with an approximate duration of 2 hours 30 minutes and then, the 128 obtained product was transferred into the electric mantle at an operating temperature of 129 100oC. While heating at the temperature of 100oC, excess water content is dehydrated 130 and then a transparent viscous gel was obtained. The obtained viscous gel undergoes a 131 strong self-propagation combustion process after a specified duration of period and 132 then, a product of porous foam nanoparticles which is in yellow colour is produced. The 133 gasses such as water vapor, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen were exhausted in large 134 quantity in the form of brown fumes throughout the entire chemical reaction. The 135 manufactured nanoparticle was annealed at an operating condition of a temperature of 136 650OC and duration of 2 hours.
137 Structural morphology and crystalline phase of the manufactured nanoparticles was 138 examined by X-Ray diffractometer (PAnalyticalX’pert PRO) using Cu-Kα radiation
139 (1.504). Figure.1 depicts the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of obtained cerium oxide 140 nanoparticles and it was annealed at an approximate temperature of 620° C. All the 141 peaks of diffraction were indexed to pure cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 nanoparticle 142 and coincide well with the card No. 81-07920 of the Joint Committee on Powder 143 Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). The average particle size of the CeO2 nanoparticle size 144 of the obtained sample was examined from the preferential orientation (111) by 145 employing Debye-Scherer formula
146 𝐷 = 𝐹v
𝑑𝑐𝑜𝑠𝜃
147 Where D is the particle size of the mean CeO2 nanoparticle, F is the shape factor and its 148 magnitude is 0.9, v is the x-ray wavelength and its magnitude is 1.5416 Å for Cu-Kα, d 149 is full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the diffraction peak and θ is the Bragg’s 150 angle. The mean particle size was found to be 15.21 nm.
151 Figure.2 depicts the scanning electron microscope (SEM) micrograph of obtained ceria 152 nanoparticles. SEM shows a big collection of particles with high porous nature and this 153 nature is generally found in the method of combustion synthesis of ceria nanoparticles. 154 It was ascribed to the ejection of gasses during the combustion process. Figure.3 155 depicted the Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) spectrum of CeO2 nanoparticle 156 which affirms the mien of cerium and oxygen elements in the composition. Figure.4 157 depicts the transmission electron microscope (TEM) morphology of CeO2 nanoparticles 158 by the combustion process. The image shows the crystallites with small agglomeration 159 and forming aggregates. The polygonal shaped particle sizes vary in the range from 19 160 nm to 50 nm which was slightly larger than the results obtained from the XRD (Dey et
161 al. 2008; Mogensen et al. 2000; Gao et al. 2010;). Generally, cerium oxide nanoparticles 162 have good conductivity and thermal stability (Sajeevan, & Sajith, 2013; Jin et al. 2010). 163 The specification of the CeO2 nanoparticle is tabulated in Table 1.
164 2.2 Outline of Nerium oleander biofuel. 165 Nerium oleander is widely cultivated as a decorative evergreen shrub or as an informal 166 hedge in warm-temperate and dry subtropical regions. In India, it is mostly cultivated 167 in the road dividing structures on highways for ornamental purpose. Nerium is the only 168 species currently classified in the genus. It is most commonly known as oleander. It 169 belongs to the family of Apocynaceae and all parts of the plant are highly toxic. It grows 170 up to 6.5 m with erect stems which splay outwards when it is matured. During the first 171 year, stems have a glaucous bloom and they become grayish bark when matured. It 172 consists of pairs of leaves or whole of three, thick and leathery, dark-green, narrowly 173 lanceolate, 6–22 cm long and 1–3.5 cm broad, and with an entire margin. At the end of 174 each branch, flowers are grown in clusters, it looks like white, pink to red in colour and 175 diameter of the flower is approximately 2.5 -5 cm, with a deeply 5-lobed fringed corolla 176 round the central corolla tube. The nerium fruit consists of long narrow capsule about 177 5- 23cm long, which splits open at maturity to release numerous downy seeds.
178 The kernels are randomly picked from the nerium oleander plant, cracked using a 179 hammer and the seeds obtained are weighed using the digital weighing machine. To 180 remove the moisture content from the seeds, they are kept in open air for 96 hours and 181 crushed using corona mechanical grinder. The nerium oleander biofuel is extracted 182 through manually operated mechanical screw and weighed. The Structural formula for 183 nerium oleander is C32H48O9 and its molecular weight is 576. It consists about 25%
184 oxygen, 8.33% hydrogen and 66.66% carbon atoms. The physio-chemical properties of 185 nerium oleander seed oil had been thoroughly studied by Yadav et al 2017, 2016. The 186 free fatty acid content of the biodiesel is of 3.92 % and it consists of α-tocopherol, 187 oleandrine and the roots contain steroids (Garima & Amla 2010). Authors had stated 188 that the neat nerium oleander biofuel could be used as fuel in diesel engine mostly 189 because of its properties which are closer to those of diesel (Nwakaire, & Durugu, 190 2013).
191 2.3 Test fuel preparation 192 Emulsions are usually prepared by amalgamating two non-miscible liquids in the mien 193 of stabilizer called as a surfactant. The surfactant permits the emulsions to be in stable 194 condition, even if it contains oil phase. It reduces the interfacial tension of the oil and 195 allows the water droplets to be dispersed in the continuous oil phase uniformly. The 196 choice of surfactant is very important because it influences the emulsion stability and 197 its nature. From an earlier research of Annamalai et al. (2016), it has been found that 198 for water in oil emulsion hydrophilic-lipophilic balance (HLB), value for the surfactant 199 has to be less than 7 for better stability. Hence, SPAN 80 whose HLB value is 4.2 was 200 chosen as the best surfactant for making nerium oleander emulsion. Ethanol acts as a 201 co-surfactant to reduce the overall viscosity of the emulsified fuel. In preparing nerium 202 oleander emulsions, a different proportion of neat nerium oleander biofuel, water, 203 ethanol, and Span 80 was taken in a container. The contents were stirred vigorously 204 (since oil and water are immiscible) until homogeneous phase was obtained. Twenty 205 samples of emulsified fuel are prepared with different proportions of NOB, water, 206 surfactant and co-surfactant as furnished in the Table 2. Based on the stability test, it
207 has been proved that the 75% neat nerium oleander biofuel, 15% water, 5% ethanol, 208 and 5% Span 80 contained emulsified fuel has achieved higher stability when equated 209 with other samples. The ternary diagram which is shown in the figure 5 is agreeing well 210 the previous research work of Kumar et al (2016). The fluid which is dispersed with the 211 nano-sized particle is known as nanofluid. Hence, the nanofluid is prepared by 212 ultrasonicator which works on the principle of ultra-sonic cavitation which is used to 213 disperse the nanoparticle in the water. For our requirement, around 15% of water by its 214 volume was taken to disperse 30 ppm of cerium oxide nanoparticle in a beaker. The 215 beaker containing water and nanoparticle was kept below the anvil of the ultrasonic 216 cavitator. Vibration amplitude of 20 µm and vibration frequency of around 20 kHz was 217 fixed by tuning the control knob. Ultrasonicator was allowed to operate for a period of 218 30 minutes for the complete dispersion of nanoparticle in the water. Thus, the cerium 219 oxide nanofluid was prepared by the above-mentioned method. After the preparation of 220 ceria nanofluid from the ultrasonic cavitator, the nanofluid was mixed with 75% nerium 221 oleander, 5% surfactant and 5% co-surfactant by volume basis in the container for 222 nanofluid emulsion preparation by means of mechanical stirrer. Then, the container was 223 kept below the mechanical stirrer and allowed to run around 1500 rpm for 30 minutes 224 in the atmospheric condition for complete mixing of water-nerium oleander nanofluid 225 emulsion. Finally, the nerium oleander nano biofuel was prepared by the above method. 226 The physiochemical properties of test fuels were measured as per the ASTM standard 227 and they are listed in Table.3
228 2.4. Engine set-up and experiments conducted
229 The experimental engine set-up employed in this research work consisted of a 230 mono-cylinder, 4-stroke, water-cooled, direct injection diesel engine developing a power 231 output of 5.2 kW. The standard diesel engine’s technical details are given in Table.4. 232 The engine was loaded using eddy current dynamometer (Benz). The engine was 233 attached to a large tank which was connected through the orifice meter, to make an air 234 flow measurement. An optical encoder was used to give signals at Top Dead Center 235 (TDC). The rated power of 5.2 kW was produced by the engine and ran at an unvarying 236 speed of 1500 revolution per minute (rpm). The criterion injection pressure of the 237 manufactured engine is 200 bar. Using stopwatch and burette, the fuel flow rate was 238 measured on the volumetric basis. Digas analyzer (AVL) was used for measuring the 239 hydrocarbon (HC), oxides of nitrogen (NOX) and carbon monoxide (CO) emission in the 240 tailpipe exhaust. The Smoke opacity emission was obtained by using a standard smoke 241 meter (AVL-415). During entire investigations, the injection timing was set at 27 oC 242 before TDC for all the tested fuels. All measurements were taken, after the engine had 243 become thermally stabilized. The experimental engine test was conducted four times 244 and then the obtained readings were averaged for better accuracy. The block diagram of 245 the experimental diesel engine set-up used for the research work is shown in figure.6. 246 The evaluations of the uncertainty in the current measurements were carried out by 247 following the procedure of Huang et al. (2016). The uncertainty in the measurement are 248 furnished in the Table 5. The uncertainty percentage of experiment conducted was 249 calculated to be 1.85%.
250 3. Results and discussion 251 3.1 Performance characteristics
252 3.1.1 Brake thermal efficiency 253 The comparison of brake thermal efficiency (BTE) for dissimilar fuels viz. SFDF, NOB, 254 ENOB and NENOB at various power outputs are depicted in figure.7. The BTE of the 255 IC engine is defined as the efficiency with which the chemical energy of the fuel is 256 converted into mechanical work output inside the combustion chamber. The thermal 257 efficiency gains with a raise in load of the engine due to the raise of temperature of the 258 engine wall. The BTE of the neat NOB was least when equated with all other fuels 259 because of its higher magnitude of density and viscosity, which ensued in inferior 260 combustion occurring inside the combustion zone. The BTE of ENOB was higher when 261 equated with the neat NOB because of the secondary atomization, microexplosion and 262 reduction in overall viscosity of the nerium oleander emulsion due to the addition of 263 water molecule and ethanol about 15% and 5% respectively on a volume basis. The 264 result is agreeing well with the previous finding of by Kumar et al. (2005). Neat ENOB 265 had 27.2% BTE, whereas neat NOB had 24.8% at rated power output condition. As the 266 ENOB reaches the temperature beyond the boiling point of water (ie.100oC), the 267 emulsified fuel rapidly evaporated and busted due to the presence of water molecules. 268 During bursting, large sized fuel droplets are broken into fine and smaller droplets, 269 which ensued in a more complete vaporization rate and higher turbulent mixing of the 270 fuel. The micro-explosion is defined as the process in which fuel burst inside the engine 271 cylinder, whereas secondary atomization is defined as the process of dividing larger fuel 272 droplet into very fine and smaller droplets. Furthermore, BTE of the NENOB 273 heightened when equated with neat NOB and ENOB, due to speedy vaporization rate 274 and bettered atomization owing to the large surface area to volume ratio of cerium oxide
275 nanoparticle as reported by Arockiasamy, & Anand, (2015). Important features of ceria 276 nanoparticle are the ability to break the molecules of hydrogen present in the water of 277 nerium oleander nanoemulsion fuel and the separated high flame velocity of hydrogen 278 atom which participates in the combustion process and raises the BTE (Basha, & Anand, 279 2012). At full load condition, the BTE of NENOB exhibits 20% and 30% increased 280 BTE when equated with neat NOB and ENOB, whereas 20% reduced BTE was 281 obtained when equated with SFDF. At the rated power output, the BTE of NENOB was 282 29.35%, whereas the BTE of SFDF was 31.8%.
283 3.1.2 Brake specific energy consumption 284 The comparison of brake specific energy consumption (BSEC) for dissimilar fuels viz. 285 SFDF, NOB, ENOB and NENOB at various power outputs is depicted in figure.8. The 286 brake specific energy consumption in the IC engine is defined as the quantity of energy 287 consumed by an engine to produce the power of one Kilo-Watt in one hour. The BSEC 288 of the neat nerium oleander is greater than that of all other test fuels due to its reduced 289 calorific value and its higher viscosity. The BSEC of the ENOB is lesser than that of 290 neat NOB owing to two important factors which are secondary atomization and micro291 explosion which in turn resulted in a heightened evaporation rate and heightened mixing 292 rate of the fuel as reported by Kumar et al. (2005). Neat ENOB had 13.33 MJ/kWh of 293 BSEC, whereas neat NOB had 14.21 MJ/kWh at full load condition. The BSEC of the 294 nanoemulsion of nerium oleander biofuel was further reduced when equated with neat 295 NOB and ENOB because of the raise in the calorific value of the fuel due to the addition 296 of ceria nanoparticles. The unburned hydrocarbon which gets posited in the wall of the 297 engine cylinder are oxidized by nanoparticle which in turn reduce the brake specific
298 energy consumption significantly (Arockiasamy & Anand 2015). At full load condition, 299 the BTE of NENOB exhibits 20% and 30% reduced BSEC when equated with neat 300 NOB and ENOB, whereas 20% increased BTE was obtained when equated with SFDF. 301 The BSEC of NENOB was 12.54 MJ/kWh, whereas SFDF had 11.75 MJ/kWh at rated 302 power output.
303 3.2 Emission magnitude 304 3.2.1 Hydrocarbon emission 305 The comparison of hydrocarbon (HC) for dissimilar fuels viz. SFDF, NOB, ENOB and 306 NENOB at various power outputs is depicted in figure.9. The unburned hydrocarbon 307 was formed due to the incomplete combustion inside the combustion chamber. It is 308 attributed to the fuel richness and lower engine cylinder wall temperature. The quantum 309 of HC emission increases with an increase in engine brake power, owing to higher 310 quantity of fuel, which is supplied to the engine cylinder to produce the higher power 311 output. The HC emission of neat NOB was lower at all power outputs when compared 312 with all other test fuels because of high oxygen molecules present in the fuel which 313 ensued incomplete combustion. The HC emission of the ENOB heightened when 314 equated with neat nerium oleander because of the presence of 15% of water molecule 315 which is added in the emulsion of nerium oleander biofuel and this water molecule 316 results in reduced temperature of the engine cylinder and poor combustion (Chen et al. 317 2015). Neat emulsion of nerium oleander had 58 ppm of HC emission, whereas neat 318 NOB had 55 ppm at full load condition. The HC emission for nanoemulsion of nerium 319 oleander biofuel was less when equated with all other test fuels. This is due to the 320 presence cerium oxide nanoparticle which acts as oxidization agent (Sajith et al. 2010).
321 Unburned HC emission of NENOB was reduced by 36.3% when equated with SFDF at 322 rated power output. At full load condition, the NENOB exhibits 20% and 30% reduced 323 HC emission when equated with neat NOB, ENOB and SFDF respectively. The 324 hydrocarbon and cerium oxide react to form various products such as carbon dioxide, 325 water and cerous oxide. The above mentioned chemical reaction is presented by the 326 succeeding equation:
327 (2y+x)CeO2 + HxCy → [(2y+x)/2] Ce2O3 + x/2H2O + y/2CO2 (1)
328 3.2.2 Carbon monoxide emission 329 The comparison of CO emission for dissimilar fuels viz. SFDF, NOB, ENOB and 330 NENOB at various power outputs are depicted in figure.10. The CO emission occurs 331 due to the deficiency of oxygen molecules in the engine cylinder and it is the 332 intermediate chemical compound produced during the process of combustion. The CO 333 emission lowered due to the rise of combustion chamber temperature up to 4.16 kW. 334 The CO emission increased dramatically owing to the richness of the fuel for all the test 335 fuels at 100% of loading condition. The CO emission of the NOB was decreased when 336 equated with standard diesel fuel. The decreased CO emission could be attributed to the 337 fact that neat NOB had rich oxygen content and thus, resulted in lower carbon monoxide 338 emission. Neat NOB had 0.182% of carbon monoxide emission, whereas SFDF had 339 0.195% at full load condition. CO emission of the ENOB was increased when equated 340 with the neat NOB. It could be ascribed to the fact that ENOB contains 15% of water, 341 which in turn reduced the temperature of the engine cylinder and the rate of combustion 342 simultaneously (Sajith et al. 2010). Neat ENOB had 0.186% of CO emission, whereas 343 neat NOB had 0.182% of CO emission at full load condition. Further, CO emission was
344 reduced for NENOB when equated with all other test fuels because of heightened 345 evaporation rate and heightened mixing rate which are due to the addition of the cerium 346 oxide nanoparticle which in turn acts as an oxidation catalyst. Thus, the cerium oxide 347 reacts with carbon monoxide to form carbon dioxide (Basha et al. 2011). The carbon 348 monoxide emission of a nanoemulsion of nerium oleander got reduced by 20.5% when 349 equated with SFDF at rated power output. The above-mentioned chemical reaction is 350 presented by the succeeding equation:
351 2CeO2 + CO → Ce2O3 + CO2 (2)
352 3.2.3 Oxides of nitrogen 353 The comparison of NOX emission for dissimilar fuels viz. SFDF, NOB, ENOB and 354 NENOB at various power outputs is depicted in figure.11. Nitrogen gas reacts with 355 oxygen molecules at higher temperature to form oxides of nitrogen emission. In the 356 present study, availability of oxygen and higher in-cylinder temperature enhanced the 357 NOX emission for neat NOB when equated with the SFDF. It may be ascribed to the 358 rich oxygen molecules present in the neat nerium oleander biofuel, which in turn 359 enhanced the NOX emission. Neat NOB had 705 ppm of NOX emission, whereas SFDF 360 had 675 ppm at full load condition. The NOX emission was reduced for ENOB when 361 compared with neat NOB. This may be due to the addition of water and ethanol content 362 in the emulsion of nerium oleander biofuel, which in turn significantly decreased the 363 temperature of the cylinder because of water’s higher magnitude of latent heat of 364 vaporization (Kannan, & Anand, 2011). ENOB had 655 ppm of NOX emission, whereas 365 NOB had 705 ppm at full load condition. The lowered magnitude of oxides of nitrogen 366 emission was observed for the NENOB when equated with all other test fuels due to the
367 addition of nanoparticle which acts as reducing agent. Cerium oxide reacts with HC and 368 CO and cerous oxide is formed individually (Dowding et al. 2012). Thus, the cerous 369 oxide further reacts with nitrogen oxide to produce nitrogen and cerium oxide, which 370 in turn significantly reduce the formation of NOX emission. At full load condition, the 371 NENOB shows 20% and 30% reduced HC emission respectively when equated with 372 neat NOB, ENOB and SFDF respectively. The above-mentioned chemical reaction is 373 presented by the succeeding equation.
374 Ce2O3 + NO → 2CeO2 + 1/2N2
375 3.2.4 Smoke opacity emission 376 The comparison of smoke opacity emission for dissimilar fuels viz. SFDF, NOB, ENOB 377 and NENOB at various power output is depicted in figure.12. The smoke opacity 378 emission was enhanced with the increase in engine load due to the addition of excess 379 amount of fuel that was injected to produce higher power output. The smoke is nothing 380 but the unburned carbon molecules that appear in the tailpipe exhaust gasses or infringe 381 on the wall of the combustion chamber and in the tailpipe system of exhaust. Smoke 382 emission of the NOB was least when equated with SFDF owing to the presence of 383 oxygen content in the fuel. Neat NOB consists of 25% of oxygen content by its whole 384 weight. Neat NOB had 68% of smoke opacity emission, whereas SFDF had 72.4% at 385 full load condition. The smoke opacity emission was reduced for ENOB when equated 386 with neat NOB. It could be ascribed due to two important factors viz. Secondary 387 atomization and micro explosion which in turn lead to better atomization which ensued 388 in better combustion eventually (Yang et al. 2013). ENOB had 64% of smoke opacity 389 emission, whereas NOB had 68% at full load condition. Smoke emission was even less
390 for NENOB when equated with all other test fuels. It may be ascribed to the presence 391 of ceria nanoparticle, which ameliorates the evaporation rate of the fuel (Basha, & 392 Anand, 2011c). At full load condition, the NENOB express 20% and 30% reduced 393 smoke opacity emission when equated with neat NOB, ENOB and SFDF respectively.
394 3.3 Combustion analysis 395 3.3.1 Cylinder pressure 396 The relationship between cylinder pressure and crank angle emission for dissimilar 397 fuels viz. SFDF, NOB, ENOB and NENOB at rated power output is depicted in 398 figure.13. From figure, it is clear that the neat NOB has lower cylinder pressure when 399 equated with all other test fuels due to its higher magnitude of density and viscosity and 400 these properties of fuel lead to poor evaporation rate which in turn results in inferior 401 combustion. ENOB shows greater cylinder pressure when equated with neat NOB 402 because of the presence of 10% of water molecules in the fuel, which in turn leads to 403 lower values of cetane number which in turn leads to longer period of ignition delay, 404 which in turn results in large quantity of fuel being injected inside the combustion zone 405 and its sudden burning (Prabu, & Anand, 2016). NENOB shows least engine cylinder 406 pressure when equated with standard diesel because of the shorter ignition delay period, 407 which is ascribed to the addition of cerium oxide nanoparticle to the emulsion of nerium 408 oleander, which in turn leads to increased magnitude of cetane number and the reduced 409 period of ignition delay which in turn results in less engine’s in-cylinder pressure. At 410 the rated power output, the standard diesel had high cylinder pressure of 71.443 bar, 411 whereas the neat NOB, NO emulsion, and NO nanoemulsion recorded 64.39bar, 68.50 412 bar, and 65.024 bar respectively.
413 3.3.2 Heat release rate 414 The relationship between heat release rate (HRR) and crank angle for different fuels 415 viz. SFDF, NOB, ENOB and NENOB at rated power output is shown in figure.14. 416 Nerium oleander nanoemulsion biofuel had lower HRR when compared with neat diesel 417 due to the addition of cerium oxide nanoparticle which in turn resulted in the lowering 418 of in-cylinder temperature due to its thermal conductivity. Standard fossil diesel fuel 419 had a maximum magnitude of HRR about 76.3 kJ/m3degree, whereas the neat NOB, 420 NO emulsion, and NO nanoemulsion recorded HRR about 65 kJ/m3degree, 71.9 421 kJ/m3degree and 67.02 kJ/m3degree respectively.
422 4. Conclusion 423 Based on the experimental research studies, the succeeding conclusions were arrived:
424  Based on the stability test, it has been found that 75% NOB, 15% water, 5% 425 surfactant and 5% co-surfactant mixture content of emulsion fuel has higher 426 stability of 62 hours when equated with the other tested samples.
427  The brake thermal efficiency and the brake specific fuel consumption of cerium 428 oxide nanoparticle mixed with the nerium oleander emulsion biofuel were found 429 to be enhanced when equated with neat nerium oleander biofuel owing to its 430 large surface area to volume ratio of nanoparticle which in turn results in 431 complete combustion.
432  The nerium oleander nanoemulsion fuel causes a reduction in CO and HC 433 tailpipe emission when equated with nerium oleander and neat diesel fuel, due
434 to the presence of cerium oxide nanoparticle which acts as an oxidation agent 435 and due to the presence of oxygen content in the fuel.
436  There was a reduction of NOX emission for nerium oleander nanoemulsion fuel 437 when equated with raw nerium oleander and the standard diesel owing to very 438 high magnitude of latent heat of vaporization of the water molecule that is 439 present in the fuel as well as the due to the presence of the cerium oxide 440 nanoparticle which acts as a reducing agent.
441  The use of nerium oleander nano emulsion fuel caused a reduction in smoke 442 opacity emission when equated with raw nerium oleander emulsion and the 443 standard diesel fuel due to secondary atomization, microexplosion and increased 444 evaporation rate which in turn is due to the addition of ceria nanoparticle.
445  From the overall experimental observation, it could be concluded that the cerium 446 oxide nanoparticle mixed with an emulsion of nerium oleander biofuel is the 447 most promising fuel, without any hardware modification in the engine and is 448 capable of reducing the environmental pollution.
449  The limitation of the research work, even though the harmful tailpipe emission 450 has stepped down, the efficiency lies well below the diesel fuel. At the rated 451 power output, the BTE of NENOB was 29.35%, whereas the BTE of SFDF was 452 31.8%. The diesel engine is optimized for the diesel fuel, rather for the NENOB. 453 The diesel engine needs certain engine modification to have thermal efficiency 454 comparable to diesel.
455  As a part of the future scope, the current research work can be extended in a way 456 by varying the fuel injection parameters such as injection timing and injection
457 pressure for the diesel engine operated with nanoemulsion of nerium oleander 458 biofuel.
459  The current research work can be extending in a way by modifying the 460 combustion bowl to improve the efficiency and a spotlight can be made on the 461 addition of anti-oxidant to the fuel mixture to enhance the properties for the 462 diesel engine operated with nanoemulsion of nerium oleander biofuel.

referenceMentions.context: High demand and lavish consumption have led to the depletion of fossil 36 fuels like petroleum products and government’s strict emission standard forced us to 37 use alternative fuels such as ethanol, n-butanol, dimethyl ethers, mimusops elengi linn 38 and cotton methyl ester (Pedrozo et al. 2016; Zhang and Balasubramanian, 2016; Bora 39 et al. 2014; Hazar, 2010).
